content.rendered:
A minimalist identity sandwiched in between a couple of maximalist projects today, with work from Yerevan, Barcelona, and Manila.

The Shack by Backbone Branding

The Shack is a seafood restaurant in Abu Dhabi with an American angle to it — think a refined Red Lobster with a chic rustic look. The identity by Yerevan, Armenia-based Backbone Branding features a great logo where the “THE” in the name is made up of wood planks and arranged like a shack. It’s a simple pleasure to see it happen. It’s not the best shack representation ever but the idea comes across instantly and, more importantly, it begins to convey the feel of the restaurant. The logo is complemented by a series of spray-painted illustrations of lobsters, crabs, squids, and more, repeated in circular patterns. I’m not sure if that’s the best complement for the logo — although spray paint on wood, yes, it works — but they provide a great texture and fun vibe. Some cool process photos at the bottom of the link. See full project

Maki by Javier Arizu, Guillem Casasús, Anna Berbiela, and Carlos Bermúdez

Maki is a concept art, um, artist and illustrator somewhere in Spain (or at least that’s where his cell phone in the business card is from) and of all the concept art artists and illustrators I know he has the best identity, designed by a consortium of designers — who appeared on Friday Likes 157 with La Revolución and desperately need a company name if they are going to keep doing cool shit together. The identity revolves around an abstract, flexible “M” that can stretch and adapt to any canvas and still read as an “M” as well as convert the top of almost any business collateral into an “M”. Expensive but classy. The full wordmark has a nice extra touch in that the “K” is a rotated “M”. You do you, Maki! See full project

Churreria La Lola by And A Half

Churreria La Lola is a chain of eight (so far) quick-service restaurants in the Philippines specializing in one of the most delicious things ever, churros. The identity by Manila-based And A Half is a concoction of a superb condensed slab serif, funny illustrations (not shown above but plenty at the link), and a killer triangular pattern that matches the shape of the churro-holding packaging which has its own, integrated cup holder for a small serving of dipping chocolate to dunk those churros. The colors are meant to represent the Mexican flag, since that’s where churros originated. Overall, this is a brand that is clearly having fun with its product and the excitement extends to all their promotions and materials. See full project
